content: The "Enterprise Capital Formation Act of 1995" encourages investments in small business venture capital stock by providing tax incentives for individuals and corporations. The Act modifies the exclusion of gain on certain small business stock to further incentivize investments in capital assets. The "Enterprise Capital Formation Act of 1995" increases the exclusion percentage for small business stock to 75%. It also allows corporations to qualify for the exclusion and prohibits stock held within a controlled group from being eligible. Additionally, the Act repeals the minimum tax preference. The "Enterprise Capital Formation Act of 1995" increases the exclusion percentage for small business stock to 75% and allows corporations to qualify for the exclusion. It also amends various sections of the tax code, including increasing the asset limitation from $50,000,000 to $100,000,000 and providing for an inflation adjustment of the asset limitation for stock issued after 1996. The "Enterprise Capital Formation Act of 1995" makes changes to the tax code, including repealing the per-issuer limitation in section 1202 and modifying the working capital limitation. The "Enterprise Capital Formation Act of 1995" amends section 1202 of the tax code to provide exceptions for stock redemption rules based on business purpose. The amendments apply to stock issued after December 31, 1994, with an option to apply to qualified stock issued after August 10, 1993. The "Enterprise Capital Formation Act of 1995" amends section 1202 of the tax code to provide exceptions for stock redemption rules. Qualified stock refers to stock held by the taxpayer on December 31, 1994, which would be qualified small business stock if the amendments applied to stock issued after August 10, 1993. The "Enterprise Capital Formation Act of 1995" amends section 1202 of the tax code to treat qualified stock as sold and reacquired on January 1, 1995, at its fair market value. Any resulting gain is recognized on that date.
